post.heading: Prior Art Relevant to Patent US 11230032
post.p: The patent in question was filed on Apr 13, 2018. We will refer to the patented contraption as SkyBAAM, or "the patented contraption", for short. We will present prior art relevant to SkyBAAM, all of which was unmentioned and unreferenced in the patent. The prior art we present will mostly have been published within context of the open source project called Hangprinter.

The patent made only two references to Hangprinter:
The Wikipedia Article
An out of date article from 3ders.org
Those two sources alone do not cover enough details to reveal how deeply similar SkyBAAM is to the pre-existing Hangprinter.
The patent contains many ideas that have been explored, published, and then discontinued within the Hangprinter community.
The Hangprinter prototype that was most visually similar to Fig 4 in the patent might be this early version 3 prototype, that was published and described in detail on April 4, 2017.

figure.figcaption: The video shows the first Hangprinter prototype that offloaded the motors and most of the electronics to one of the anchors.
Fig 4 from from the patent in question.

post.p: If you look closely in the video, you'll see anchors that are very similar to this:

figure.figcaption: Fig 7 from from the patent in question.

post.p: It's not only technical objects in the patent that bear similarities with prior Hangprinter publications. Their artistic expression is also strikingly similar.

figure.figcaption: This image was published in a blog post on 24 Feb, 2017.
Fig 2 from from the patent in question.

The video shows how the 3d animation covering hangprinter.org's front page for a full year before the patent in question was filed. hangprinter.org was launched on Apr 4, 2017, and the animation was there until it was replaced on 21 Sep, 2020.

post.p:
The artistic expression (as well as the physical implementation), of an unfinished circular tower with tall arched windows, and a thick helical structure along the outer wall, being 3d printed by a cable driven parallel robot with four cable-directions, one of which is near vertical, driving an effector with rotational degrees of freedom being constrained by pairs of generally parallel cables, of which anchors (called base stations in the patent) are potentially lifted above ground level with thin tall structures, was published widely on all 3d printing news sites in Feb/March 2017, a year before the patent was filed. Examples of such news articles include, but are not limited to:
fabbaloo.com
3dnatives.com
archdaily.com
3dprintingindustry.com
3dprint.com

However, the similarities between the patented contraption and Hangprinter are not merely superficial. This text will show similarities on the conceptual level in the form of ideas that were formulated, and sometimes also implemented within the Hangprinter Project, before they were reiterated in the patent.

This writing will be long and detailed. The corpus of relevant prior art published publicly before April 13 2018 is vast, since the Hangprinter Project was already four years old at the time. This prior art includes, but is not limited to:
56 technical blog posts
Ca 350 posts on Reprap forums
thread 1
thread 2
thread 3
A few hundred posts in the Facebook group
Ca 25 relevant Youtube videos
37 videos published on Vimeo
Ca 100 Tweets
13 Hangprinter Newsletters
Wiki articles on Appropedia, and Reprap Wiki.
The hangprinter.org landing page
A public Github repo containing over 500 relevant commits and issues
A number of news articles, including but not limited to these
hackaday.com
hackaday.com again
3dprintingindustry.com
seeker.com
sciencedaily.com
fabbaloo.com
wired.com
3dprint.com
post.h2: Prior Art Published in the Repo
post.p: The main Hangprinter repo is the heart of the Hangprinter project.

Hangprinter is developed following open source methodology. This means that all source files are published to the repo, freely for anyone to use, for any purpose, soon after they are created. They are also re-uploaded soon after any modification is made.

The re-uploads do not overwrite old work. Instead, each change is registered in an elaborate version control system (git/Github), that presents the newest version to the user, as well as saving and catalouging every previous version in chronological order. Catalouged versions are available through git and the Github web interface.

The "source files" include, but are not limited to
CAD drawings
Source code for programming the firmware of any microcontrollers involved
Assembly and usage instructions
A copyright license
The version controlled, and publicly available directory that serves the source files to the general public is called "the repo". It can be found here.
The general public had access and usage rights to the repo continously at all times since Dec 15, 2014, including on Apr 13, 2018.

Information about how popular and well known the repo was on Apr 13, 2018 can be found by using archive.org, also known as Wayback Machine. It is a service that stores and archives old web pages, so we can visit them again, and see exactly how they looked on given dates, superficially similar to how the git/Github saving and catalouging works. However, it does not save every web page every day, so the investigated dates will precede Apr 13, 2018 by weeks or months.
This is how github.com/tobbelobb/hangprinter looked on Jun 26, 2017:

figure.figcaption: Click the image for a larger version.

post.p: In the image we can see that the repo had 77 watchers, 248 stars, and 49 forks. This means that this was a popular repo at the time. The 49 forks means that at least 49 people have copied Hangprinter's source files to use as the basis for their own cable driven robot build.
The license in the repo allows and encourages such copying. Hangprinter was the most popular and widely known basis for cable driven robot development in 2017 and 2018.
On Apr 13, 2018 the Hangprinter version 2 development had just been concluded (this happened on Feb 12, 2018). Work on Hangprinter version 3 had been going on since April 2017.
The state of the art of version 2 in the repo on Apr 13, 2018 can be found in the Github catalouge, here.
The state of the art of version 3 in the repo on Apr 13, 2018 can be found in the Github catalouge, here.
This is how a state-of-the art Hangprinter version 3 looked like in CAD on Apr 10, 2018, according to the repo:

figure.figcaption: Click the image for a larger version. All individual parts were finished, but the file that renders their assembly was not finished. Still, we can clearly see the intent of having motors offloaded from the effector.

post.p: This is how a state-of-the art Hangprinter version 2 looked like in CAD on Apr 10, 2018, according to the repo:

figure.figcaption: Click the image for a larger version. This is largely similar to the machine we saw in the 2017 news articles linked above.

post.p: The firmware was also published in the same repo along with instructions of how to use them:

figure.figcaption: Click the image for a larger version. This is the README file from the firmware directory of the repo.

post.p: A README file is common to include in any open source public repo, to help users understand how the source files are meant to be used. The firmwares of Hangprinter version 2 and Hangprinter version 3 were identical and interchangeable apart from default configuration values.

The above README file told users of Hangprinter version 3, visiting on Apr 10, 2018, what they needed to know in order to use the firmware. Since the text in the image is very small, I will quote some important parts to highlight them.

"Both Hangprinter v2 (master branch) and Hangprinter v3 (Gbg_version_3 branch) uses
- Arduino Mega + RAMPS running and old fork or Marlin, contained in this directory
- Three or four Mechaduino controlled steppers, running the firmware in the Mechaduino_subtree directory"

The quote made clear that users had a choice to omit one of the four motors if they wanted to. This is because only 3 degrees of freedom are strictly needed to define a point in 3D space, as described in the patent.

Because cables can only pull, and not push the effector, at least one more force vector needs to work on the effector, in addition to those from the three lines themselves, in order to keep all lines tight. Some users preferred to use gravity, springs, and other tension controlling mechanisms, rather than buy a fourth motor and a fourth set of cables.
The second quote from the README describes a "tension controlling mechanism":

"Mechaduinos are there to provide closed loop control (no skipped steps), torque mode, and for making automatic calibration (locating anchor points) possible. See https://vimeo.com/227893849 and https://vimeo.com/227891846 for demos of torque mode and autocal data collection."

A Mechaduino is a type of circuit board that controls the movement of one motor, executing commands sent to it by the central controller, which is another circuit board. By sending a special command to the Hangprinter, the user could put any motor into "torque mode", and specify a requested constant torque. This would cause the motor to exert a constant torque on the cable rewinder, in the direction that winds cable inwards, creating a constant tension in the attached cable. Here's one of the linked videos that demonstrate it:

figure.figcaption: Video published August 1, 2017, demonstrating how one can drag Hangprinter around by hand when in Torque mode (called tension control in the patent).

Another video published on August 1, 2017, demonstrating how one can drag Hangprinter around by hand when in Torque mode (called tension control in the patent). In this case the tension control is used to help collect auto calibration data.

post.p: This is an example of a "tension control mechanism", frequently mentioned in the patent.

Although the patent doesn't mention kinematics transforms in detail, I will mention Hangprinter's briefly here, to make the case that Hangprinter was capable of doing a superset of the effector movements that the authors envision in the patent.

figure.figcaption: Click the image for a larger version. We see here that Hangprinter calculates its desired line lenghts by using Pythagoras' theorem on all its four cable directions.

post.p: The anchors can therefore be placed at arbitrary positions around the print volume, and the firmware will still work.

The values of anchor_A_z, anchor_B_z, and anchor_C_z describe the z-positions of the three normally lower placed anchors. These three values, as well as all the other anchor position values, can be changed mid-print, as evindenced by the widely covered 2017 tall tower print.

figure.figcaption: In this video from Apr 15, 2017, it's clear that the lines are terminated at different z-heights during different parts of the print.

post.p: All of these firmware features were being merged into the world's most used firmware at the time, called Marlin Firmware, in a public merge thread (similar to a forum thread) that was publicly available and open for anyone to read and participate in. This means Hangprinter and all its features were becoming an integrated and widely available type of 3d printer at the firmware level at the time before April 13, 2018.

In the merge thread, there were a mention of scaling Hangprinter up:
"I have seen videos on youtube , and the first thing I imagine , is the size limitless ......"

There's also an earlier merge thread with important info. Comments made publicly on Jan 9, 2018 relate to the obvious idea of adding more motion axes (called "cable rewinders" in the patent) than four to Hangprinter.
"... It's would also give us trouble the day want to add a fifth motion axis, and a couple more extruders, which is not unlikely."
"... This would allow fifth and sixth motion axes, along with additional extruders, to be easily added, but it would take some more work to implement."
post.h2: Prior Art Published On Reprap Forums
post.p: The first forum thread is 63 posts long, and 15 people took part in the open discussion. In it, I present the idea of a cable driven Reprap. You can find it here.

I will re-post some relevant images and quotes here in chronological order. Not all quotes are mine, but all images are mine. All were posted between Apr 23, 2014 and Nov 14 2017. Further details are in the forum thread.

ul.li: "... possibly introducing hardware to help keep the xy-plane wires tight..."

"The only thing we control in this system, is the length of the three wires. Every possible combination of wire-lengths, (l0, l1, l2), corresponds to a unique point in the avilable print area (a triangle). To map a point (x', y') to the corresponding wire-lengths, all we have to do is place the wires anchor-points in the cartesian coordinate system, and compute the lengths from each anchor point to the point (x', y'). Like this:"
"A setup with a dedicated z-motor, and no springs at all. This will require the four motors to work against each other to keep the lines tight."
"A sprung loaded Z motor. You then don't have to worry as much about getting all 4 motors perfectly in sync."
"Might be an interesting concept for something like cement printing?"
"You could sink poles and then string them like you would do a tent."
"You could install it outside in a large area."
"But generally this is the best concept for DIY house printing because you don't need large heavy and stiff frames or cranes."
"The one action line going to the roof could be made triple and attached to each corner of the triangular print platform to handle forces downwards."
"I love the idea of being able to print a house!"
"There's some students somewhere that executed something like this but they're printing with clay. Search "sky printer" on instructables."
"... instead of three motors you can use only two and a spring-loaded rewinder or a weight at the free end of the wire."

post.p: The second forum thread is 247 posts long, and 19 people took part in the open discussion. In it, I present and support the development of the Hangprinter version 2. You can find it here.

I will re-post some relevant images and quotes here in chronological order. Not all quotes are mine, but all images are mine. All were posted between Jan 14, 2017 and Dec 16 2017. Further details are in the forum thread.

"I think that this configuration lends itself very well to multimodal output drawing, laser CNC and 3d printing."
Then there's a discussion about where to place the motors (and therefore wire winches):
MechaBits: "Was there a reason you never went with the motors on the walls?"
tobben: "Yup several reasons, of course. One of them is that I have to tidy up after me each time I've used the printer. [part of quote left out for brevity] ..."
MechaBits: "But surely you could also do that with motors on the walls."
tobben: "Quite possible, of course. I'd love to see such a solution."
MechaBits: "I would have thought you where in a better position to mentally picture what it would look like, due to your experience with this."
tobben: "Oh yes, you would have to choose between synchronizing steppers wirelessly, drive them from a stationary PCB or to find a smart way to wind stepper cables.
Last alternative first: You could carry the stepper drivers and the microcontroller on the moving part. Signal noise because of the stepper cable lengths would be no (or a very small) problem, but they will of course have weight. You could wind in the motors when not in use and park everything in the ceiling. Nice.
Wireless motor control is probably the best solution for very big high-performance machines. You must do more programming, need more PCBs and more power supplies. The PCBs could be placed almost anywhere and you don't need to hide a lot of ugly cables. Semi nice.
With one stationary PCB and long cables to stationary motors, it will be a lot of work to make it look tidy. You will have to transform your entire room into a RepRap frame. If quick and dirty solutions, like cables taped to the floor/ceiling, works for you, and if you never need your room for something else, then this solution gives you the most print performance for your time and your buck. Or at least, that's my guess."
"Have you thought about the use of a laser pointer or rangefinder aimed at the corner that would give a digital distance to the computer? More expense that way. I have seen IR sensors that can determine distance for about 20 dollars."
"I've thought about multiple different distance measurement solutions. My pet idea right now is using draw-wire displacement sensors like this: [omitted] ... in combination with accelerometer/gyro like described here: [omitted]"
"Sensors that allow an automatic calibration and/or homing procedure. Many sensor setups could achieve this:
Metal tubes on each line that can close a circuit
Accelerometer+gyro (IMU) units
Sound sensing (maybe 1 mic + 5 speakers)
Draw-wire displacement sensors in each direction
Optical sensing from salvaged computer mice
Small touchpad area on the build plate. For example calibrating and homing with a tablet or smart phone below print head."
"Note that both the stl and the above image shows doubled lines along all axes (for mechanical advantage). [part of quite ommitted ...] If you want double mechanical advantage along A, B and C, you must specify that in Configuration.h"
We then discussed placement of anchors:
L0g4n: " ... why not put the anchor points on the ceiling as well?"
L0g4n: " ... why not put the anchor points on the ceiling as well?"
tobben: "The setup to the right would work well, especially when lines are at a ca 45 degree angle. My main reasons for not choosing it for Hangprinter was
Accelerations are limited by gravity. Maximum acceleration is equal to that of a pendulum.
Slightly trickier to park in the ceiling when not in use."
Then a comment on placement of motors, and printing of houses with concrete again.
"If you placed he motors on the frame that would give you a lighter carriage with potentially faster kinematic speeds."
"you can build complete houses with a big enough setup and a concrete dispenser as tool"
Next followed a question that touches upon some of the claims presented in the patent
L0g4n: "did you consider using just a single vertical line and account for the sled tilt due to the tension in the side lines in the math?"
tobben: "No, I never thought about this. Hangprinter currently doesn't measure tension. It measures nothing other than hot end temp. Looking forward to see a lot of sensor experimentation!"
Next we mentioned the constant force mode, later called torque mode:
"It's also possible to drive steppers in constant force mode =) See the Mechaduino Project and some ongoing discussion about that here: [www.facebook.com]"
""
""
""
""
TODO: Have only searched through pages 1, 2, 3...
post.h2: Prior Art Published On in the Facebook Group
post.p: The idea of 3d printing houses with Hangprinter was frequently discussed in the Hangprinter Facebook group around 2017 and 2018. At least one of these conversations included some visuals.

figure.figcaption: Click the image for a larger version. Screenshot from the facebook group called "Hangprinter - RepRap Project " on March 17, 2018. A person called Ed Aylward posted visuals, related to the common idea of scaling up Hangprinter for printing concrete buildings, in the facebook group, stating patent pending on the idea.

post.p: I will point out some important details in the image above. In the top right corner, we see the computer displayed the current date at the time: "Sat Mar 17 20:02". The year 2018 is confirmed in the bottom right, where it says: "Facebook © 2018"
In the top left corner, it says "public group". The group had over 200 members and increasing, already a year earlier. This was a big public group with very active discussion about Hangprinter.

Here's a part of the conversation in the screendump, suggesting a crane with wheels, as we saw in the SkyBAAM patent:
Jeff Smith: "Crane looks a bit more permanent than the building... You know they make those with wheels right?"
Ed Aylward: "yes of course"

Below the conversation, we see that Mr Aylward had posted two hours earlier:
A link to a web page
An image
A text: "3D CONCRETE BUILDING PRINTER. INVESTORS WANTED. Patents Pending, ©All rights reserved. (not to scale)"

The web page that Mr Aylward linked to in his post was saved by Wayback Machine on 28 Feb, 2018, so he had clearly created it at least a few days before posting publicly. At the time of writing this, the web page is still up.

figure.figcaption: Click the image for a larger version. The web page linked in Mr Aylward's public post.

post.p: The linked web page, as well as the image posted in the public facebook group, showed a 3d model of Hangprinter version 1, that had been copied straight from the Hangprinter repo

figure.figcaption: Click the image for a larger version. Aylward's web page displays 3d graphics, and lets us zoom in on the displayed object. We can see that this is Hangprinter version 1, and not version 2, because it does not yet use a worm gear for its D-axis (mostly vertical axis), like the Hangprinter version 2 did. If we search through Github's catalouge, we can probably pin down when it was downloaded because it includes a distinct bug: there are two motors with "B-gears", both driving the "B-lines" in the render. That bug would make the machine not work as intended in practice, and was probably removed soon after, in the real Hangprinter repo. The three low anchors are also identical to those published as Hangprinter version 1 anchors in the Hangprinter repo.
Click the image for a larger version. An illustration of the frequent and common idea of 3d printing a concrete house with Hangprinter, screendumped from Aylward's publicly linked web site.

post.p: Searching with Google Patents and PPUBS Patent Public Search with our best efforts, shows no trace of Edward Aylward's patent claim. He could have been refused, or he might not have filed for a patent afterall. We will therefore consider Aylward's publication in the public Hangprinter group as prior art.

The patent in question describes guy wires going from the D-anchor (high-up) anchor down to the anchors (base stations) with tension in them to pull the D-anchor downwards and outwards, and hence stabilizing it. See for example lines 36 in Fig 4 from their patent, near the top of this web page.

We have never used the term "guy-wire" much in the Hangprinter community. However, we've had lines going between the D-anchor and the lower anchors, just like guy wires would, since April 2017. See for example the video posted at the top of this article, or this image that was published on Dec 7, 2017:

figure.figcaption: Click the image for a larger version. Hangprinter version 3 being demonstrated on Maker Fair Rome in December 2017. Lines pulling the D-anchor down towards all three low anchors, with fixated start points and end points, are visible in the image against the white background.

post.p: Although Hangprinter's guy wires are rerouted to also serve as transmitting motion forces to the end effector, these lines double up to do the same guy-wire pulling as the static cables mentioned in the patent would do, as long as all the lines are always tight, which they always are since the machine would otherwise loose control over the effectors translational movement.

It's worth looking at the SkyDelta, and note that it too has striking similarities to the patented contraption. I won't go into the details here, but in the detailed blog post from 2013 linked above, Brandon Heller includes a video that shows similarities from an overview perspective:

figure.figcaption: Brandon Heller's Youtube video from 2013. Like most cable driven translation robots, Hangprinter included, it uses pairs of cables that are "generally parallel to each other" as it's formulated in the patent.
